title: This harrowing is going to be a mess.
body:
We all know what's going on in Biglewater. We all know how bad it's going to get this harrowing.

I just want to mention how bad it might become.

http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/game-updates/special-event/first-light-after-harrowing

I'm just here to remind everyone that a Blue Flame Leviathan was summoned, 9 years ago, to fight off the Harrowing. It manages to disperse the mist before it reaches Bilgewater, but dies in the process.

There was a talk about it here, too, of an undead Leviathan. I had many hopes of it, but we instead received Kalista. 
Perhaps this year, we'll get the giant creature of the depths to rise again.

I honestly would love to play as a giant undead sea monster. Then again, we did just get Tahm Kench, a pretty fishy champion, so i'm not sure if we'll get a new one soon.

Really, the town's not surviving the next Harrowing unless a third party intervenes.

Oh! I haven't thought about a situation where a third party intervenes. That could be pretty interesting actually.
Who do you think will help them though?

Lucian maybe?

I mean he's one guy...but his place in the new lore might make him an absolute GOD at fighting undead.
And maybe Vayne? Their teaming up together would make sense and be pretty cool.

I don't think that Vayne would object hunting undead, but I think that she's more into hunting other things such as vampires, werewolves and other night creeps (although undead are made using black magic too so yeah..).

Well, Lucian will probably pop up in at least one of the next Harrowings anyways, since that's a good place to start the undead-hunting and maybe find Thresh/a way to "kill" Thresh by fighting against the Harrowing.
Either one of the City States comes to save them, or Aatrox offers his services to Miss Fortune.

I'd personally imagine Nami helping out in some way, utilizing whatever oceanic magic she has to stem the tide of spectres raging across the sea.

Course if things get super bad it might lead to Bard having to step in and be like "Yeah no this isn't ok anymore. Before it was _kinda_ manageable, now I'm stepping in."
I don't think Bard would give much of a crap in any way. Bilgewater is just another town made by humans, finite beings, why should he care if the undead hordes overrun them?

Because said undead hordes then cross the seas and run over Valoran and then Runeterra as a whole. The potential threat for the future of Runeterra might just be to great for him not to do something about it. They've taken fleets of ships and ports, and been stopped just barely by a combined fleet of Bilgewater's populace, but if a large town like Bilgewater falls it's likely they whole archipelago does up in Black Mist. I'd imagine that prospect would make some alarm bells ring.
Honestly, I don't think Bard would care if all of Runeterra was taken over by the undead hordes of the Shadow Isles, so long as they keep away from shiny interdimensional trinkets.

His goal is to protect Runeterra from danger. That means he wants the planet to be alive and stuff. Not exactly an alive planet if it's over run by undead. It'd defeat the point of his existence if he decided it was fine letting all life on Runeterra be decimated.
He didn't seen to give two shits about the innocent powerless villagers being slaughtered wholesale...
He cared more about keeping probably-Noxus from using the orb to kill even more people.
For all we know the orb was going to explode and take the entire plateau out if he hadn't gotten it out of there.

Bard was confirmed to be some kind of reverse Terminator, he will only interfere if something/someone is of relevance in to the well-being/balance of Runaterra in the present/future.

If Bilgewater being assaulted by undeads does represent a serious threat to Runaterra in the present/future, I think Bard will interfere, but not for the sake of saving Bilgewater, but for something greater.

People may see a city as a whole, but Bard may only see a city as a part of a whole system that is Runaterra, and will only interfere if said part affect the whole system, at leas that's my interpretation of Bard.
